questions.text: A 60-year-old male came with an anterolateral myocardial infarction. The patient's condition improved over 5 days, when he developed pleuritic chest pain which persisted even after adequate analgesia and the systolic B.P. is 70 mm HG. On examination, there was marked distension of the jugular vein along with electromechanical dissociation. Most likely patient had developed the:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

External cardiac rupture Typical symptoms of a sudden decrease in BP and electromechanical dissociation seen in the first week of MI point towards a diagnosis of external cardiac rupture. Risk Factors include Increasing age Hypertension First MI Large Q wave infarct Option A - In this case, the patient will not have any pleuritic Option C - Here presentation will be of myocardial infarction but the clinical presentation will be somewhat different from this case. Option D - severe MR - no association with electromechanical dissociation .

Highyeild:

'x descent: fall in right atrial pressure after inscription of the a-wave 'y' descent: descent at the commencement of ventricular filling X' descent:- Prominent X descent:- Cardiac Tamponade ASD Constrictive Pericarditis Diminished X' descent:- TR Y descent-Prominent:- TR Constructive Pericarditis Ventricular Failure Absent / Diminished Y:- Tricuspid Stenosis Rt. Atrial Myxoma Cardiac Tamponade

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - In this case, the patient will not have any pleuritic Option C - Here presentation will be of myocardial infarction but the clinical presentation will be somewhat different from this case. Option D - severe MR - no association with electromechanical dissociation .

questions.text: Which of the following differentiates JVP from carotid pulse?

options.label: A
options.text: JVP is not easily obliterated with palpation in contrast to carotid pulse

options.label: B
options.text: Venous waveform in patients with sinus rhythm is usually biphasic

options.label: C
options.text: JVP doesn’t change with a change in posture or inspiration

options.label: D
options.text: JVP is independent of abdominal pressure

questions.correct_answer: B. Venous waveform in patients with sinus rhythm is usually biphasic
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Venous waveform in patients with sinus rhythm is usually biphasic The venous waveform in patients with sinus rhythm is usually biphasic, while the carotid pulse is monophasic.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A: JVP is easily obliterated with palpation in contrast to carotid pulse which is NOT easily obliterated. Option: B: JVP changes with a change in posture or inspiration but carotid pulse doesn’t. Option: D: JVP rises with abdominal pressure but the carotid pulse is independent.

questions.text: The jugular venous pulsation has a biphasic waveform. The wave corresponds to right atrial contraction and ends synchronously with the carotid artery pulse. The peak of the 'a' wave demarcates the end of atrial systole. The ‘ c ’ wave in the JVP waveform is due to?

options.label: B
options.text: Closed tricuspid valve pushed into the right atrium during early ventricular systole

questions.correct_answer: B. Closed tricuspid valve pushed into the right atrium during early ventricular systole
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Closed tricuspid valve pushed into the right atrium during early ventricular systole ‘a’ wave: Right atrial presystolic contraction ‘c’ wave: Closed tricuspid valve pushed into the right atrium during early ventricular systole ‘v’ wave: Atrial filling (atrial diastole) ‘x’ descent: fall in right atrial pressure after the inscription of the a-wave ‘y’ descent: descent at the commencement of ventricular filling. The JVP is the single most important bedside measurement from which to estimate the volume status. The internal jugular vein is preferred because the external jugular vein is valved and not directly in line with the superior vena cava and right atrium .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A : JVP is easily obliterated with palpation in contrast to carotid pulse which is NOT easily obliterated. Option B : JVP changes with a change in posture or inspiration but carotid pulse doesn’t . Option D : JVP rises with abdominal pressure but carotid pulse is independent.

questions.text: Hypertensive Patient comes with a history of breathlessness and chest pain on doing strenuous activity and is associated with syncope. The most likely Echo finding in this patient is.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aortic stenosis Chest pain with syncope is classical for aortic stenosis On auscultation patient will have ejection systolic murmur.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - Mitral stenosis is associated with signs and symptoms of pulmonary overload and left atrial dilatation. Option C -Mitral regurgitation is seen commonly in a patient with recent MI with cusp damage due to mitral valve prolapse Option D - Aortic regurgitation is a leaky aortic valve . When mild or moderate it is not typically of concern. Severe insufficiency can lead to heart enlargement and symptoms of heart failure so it needs to be watched closely. Severe aortic regurgitation with symptoms typically requires aortic valve replacement.

questions.text: All phases of the jugular venous pulse and their causes are correctly matched, except:

options.label: A
options.text: c' wave - the onset of atrial systole

options.label: C
options.text: y' - emptying of blood from the right atrium into right ventricle

options.label: D
options.text: v wave' - filling of the right atrium from the vena cava

questions.correct_answer: A. c' wave - the onset of atrial systole
questions.explanation:
Solution:

c' wave - the onset of atrial systole a,c,v wave = Positive wave X, Y descent = Negative wave a wave (it corresponds to S4) − atrial contraction. (Positive presystolic wave) c wave − bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during right ventricular isovolumetric systole

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B - X descent: It is a negative systolic wave (Occurs due to 2 Reasons) − Atrial relaxation Downward displacement of the tricuspid valve during ventricular systole Option C - Y descent: (It corresponds to S3)−opening of the tricuspid valve and rapid inflow of blood into right ventricle Option D - v wave − increasing volume of blood in the right atrium during ventricular systole and isovolumetric relaxation phase as the tricuspid valve is close

questions.text: A 28-year male presents to the emergency following a Road Traffic Accident where he has sustained injuries to his chest and trunk On examination HR-118bpm BP-76/60mmHg RR-28cpm. Heart sounds are muffled and JVP appears elevated. What is the Typical finding in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Absent 'Y' descent This patient has presented with hypotension, raised JVP and muffled heart sounds following an RTA which is the typical triad of cardiac tamponade cardiac tamponade is characterized by absent y descent and rapid x descent

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B - Large a wave: a. Tricuspid stenosis b. Pulmonary stenosis c. Pulmonary artery Hypertension. Option C - Absent a wave: atrial fibrillation Option D - Prominent y descent: Constrictive pericarditis, severe RHF, high venous pressure.
